sp.l: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hear it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If I had ſer'vd you right, I ſhould have ſeen
your old pate off, ere I had reveal'd.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: O wench,
oh honeſt wench; if my wife die, I'll marry thee:
There's my reward.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: 'Tis very ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Why kneel you, honeſt Maſter?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.l: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Deer Mother.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Riſe, riſe, all are friends: I owe ye
for all their boards: And wench, take thou the man
whoſe life thou ſav'dſt; leſſe cannot pay thy merit.
How ſhall I part my kiſſe? I cannot: Let
one generally therefore join our cheeks.
A pen of iron, and a leafe of braſſe,
to keep this Storie to eternitie:
and a Promethean wit. O ſacred Love,
nor chance, nor death can thy firme truth remove.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now Iſabella. Flouriſh.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: This can true love doe.
I joy they all ſo happily are pleaſ'd:
the Ladies and the brothers muſt triumph.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: They doe:
for Cupid ſcorns but t' have his triumph too.

div.stage: Enter Divers Muſicians, Then certaine Singers bearing Bannerets inſcribed, Truth, Loyaltie, Patience, Concord: Next Gerrard and Ferdinand with gar|lands of Roſes: Then Violanta: Laſt a Chariot drawn by two Cupids, and a Cupid ſitting in it. Flouriſh.

l.hi: Love, and the ſtrength of fair affection
(Moſt royall Sir) what long ſeem'd loſt have won
Their perfect ends, and crown'd thoſe constant hearts
With laſting Triumph, whoſe moſt vertuous parts,
Worthie deſires, and love, ſhall never end.
Now turn we round the Scene, and (Great Sir) lend
A ſad and ſerious eye to this of Death,
This black and diſmall Triumph; where mans breath,
Deſert, and guilty blood aſcend the Stage,
And view the Tyrant ruin'd in his rage.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, good my Lord, I am not now to finde
your long neglect of me; All thoſe affections
you came firſt clad in to my love, like Summer,
luſtie and full of life: all thoſe deſires
that like the painted Spring bloom'd round about ye,
giving the happie promiſe of an harveſt,
how have I ſeen drop off, and fall forgotten?
With the leaſt luſtre of anothers beauty,
how oft (forgetfull Lord) have I been blaſted?
Was I ſo eaſ'ly won? or did this bodie
yeeld to your falſe embraces with leſſe labour
then if you had carried ſome ſtrong towne?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Good Gabriell.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Could all your ſubtilties and ſighs betray me,
the vows ye ſhook me with, the tears ye drown'd me,
till I came fairly off with honour'd marriage?
O fie, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Prethee, good Gabriella.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Would I had never known ye, nor your honours,
they are ſtuck too full of griefs: oh happy women,
that plant your love in equall honeſt boſoms,
whoſe ſweet deſires, like roſes ſet together,
make one another happie in their bluſhes,
growing and dying without ſenſe of greatneſſe,
to which I am a ſlave! and that bleſt Sacrament
that daily makes millions of happie mothers,
link'd me to this mans luſt alone, there left me.
I dare not ſay I am his wife, 'tis dangerous:
his Love, I cannot ſay: alas, how many?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You grow too warm; pray ye be content, you beſt know
the times neceſſity, and how our marriage
being ſo much unequall to mine honour,
while the Duke lives, I ſtanding high in favour;
and whileſt I keep that ſafe, next to the Dukedome,
muſt not be known, without my utter ruine.
Have patience for a while, and doe but dream wench,
the glory of a Dutcheſſe. How ſhe tires me?
how dull and leaden is my appetite
to that ſtale beautie now? O, I could curſe
and crucifie my ſelf for childiſh doating
upon a face that feeds not with freſh figures
every freſh hour: ſhe is now a ſurfet to me.
Who's that? Gentill? I charge ye, no acquaintance
you nor your maid with him, nor no diſcourſe
till times are riper.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Fie, my noble Lord,
can you be now a ſtranger to the Court,
when your moſt vertuous Bride, the beauteous Hellena
ſtands ready like a ſtar to gild your happineſſe,
when Hymen's luſtie fires are now a lighting,
and all the flowre of Anjoy?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Some few trifles,
for matter of adornment, have a little
made me ſo ſlow, Gentille, which now in readineſſe,
I am for Court immediately.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Take heed, Sir,
this is no time for trifling, nor ſhe no Ladie
to be now entertain'd with toyes: 'twill coſt ye—

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Y' are an old Cock, Gentille.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: By your Lordſhips favour.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Prethee away; 'twill loſe time.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O my Lord,
pardon me that by all means.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: We have buſineſſe
afoot man of more moment.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Then my manners?
I know none, nor I ſeek none.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Take to morrow.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Even now, by your Lordſhips leave. Excellent Beautie,
my ever ſervice here I dedicate,
in honour of my beſt friend, your dead Father,
to you his living vertue, and wiſh heartily,
that firm affection that made us two happie,
may take as deep undying root, and flouriſh
betwixt my daughter Casta, and your goodneſſe,
who ſhall be ſtill your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I much thank ye.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: —o' this dreaming puppie. Will ye go, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A little more, Good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Not now, by —
Come, I muſt uſe ye.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Goodneſſe dwell ſtill with you. Exeunt Gentille & Lavall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: The ſight of this old Gentleman, Maria,
puls to mine eyes again the living picture
of Perolot his vertuous ſon, my firſt Love,
that dy'd at Orleance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You have felt both fortunes,
and in extreams, poor Lady: for young Perolot,
being every way unable to maintain you,
durſt not make known his love to friend or father:
My Lord Lavall, being powerfull, and you poor,
will not acknowledge you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No more: Lets in wench:
there let my Lute ſpeak my laments; they have tired me.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: I grant, the Duke is wondrous provident
in his now planting for ſucceſſion,
I know his care as honourable in the choice too,
Marines fair vertuous daughter: but what's all this?
to what end excellent arrives this travell,
when he that bears the main roof is ſo rotten?

sp.speaker: 2. Cou.
sp.l: You have hit it now indeed: For if fame lye not,
he is untemperate.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: You expreſſe him poorly,
too gentle Sir: the moſt deboiſt and barbarous;
beleeve it, the moſt void of all humanitie,
howere his cunning cloake it to his Uncle,
and thoſe his pride depends upon.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: I have herad too,
given exceſſively to drink.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: Moſt certain,
and in that drink moſt dangerous: I ſpeak theſe things
to one I know loves truth, and dares not wrong her.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: You may ſpeak on.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Uncertain as the ſea, Sir,
proud and deceitfull as his ſins great Maſter;
his appetite to women, for there he carries
his main ſail ſpread ſo boundleſſe and abominably,
that but to have her name by that tongue ſpoken,
poyſons the vertue of the pureſt Virgin.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: I am ſorry for young Gabriella then,
a maid reputed ever of faire carriage,
for he has been noted viſiting.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Shee is gone then,
or any elſe, that promiſes or power,
gifts, or his guilfull vows can work upon;
but theſe are but poor parcels.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: 'Tis great pitie.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: Nor want theſe ſins a chief ſaint to befriend 'em,
the Divell follows him; and for a truth Sir,
appears in viſible figure often to him,
at which time he 's poſſeſt with ſudden trances,
cold deadly ſweats, and griping of the conſcience,
tormented ſtrangely as they ſay.

sp.speaker: 2. Cour.
sp.l: Heaven turn him:
This marriage day maiſt thou well curſe, fair Hellen.
But let's go view the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: 1. Cour.
sp.l: I'll walk with you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Gabriella and Maria above. And Lavall, Bride, States in ſolemnitie as to marriage; and paſſe over; viz. Duke, Marine, Longavile.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I hear 'em come.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.l: Would I might never hear more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I told you ſtill: but you were ſo incredulous.
See, there they kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Adders be your embarces.
The poyſon of a rotten heart, O Hellen,
blaſt thee as I have been; juſt ſuch a flattery,
with that ſame cunning face, that ſmile upon 't,
O mark it Marie, mark it ſeriouſly,
that maſter ſmile caught me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There's the old Duke, and
Marine her father.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There Longavile—
the Ladies now.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Oh, I am murderd, Marie.
Beaſt, moſt inconſtant beaſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: There I am not;
no more I am not there: Hear me oh heaven,
and all you powers of juſtice bow down to me;
but you of pitie die. I am abuſ'd,
ſhe that depended on your Providence,
ſhe is abuſ'd: your honour is abuſ'd,
that noble peece ye made, and call'd it man,
is turn'd to divell: all the world 's abuſ'd:
Give me a womans will provok'd to miſchiefe,
a two edg'd heart; my ſuffring thoughts to wild-fires,
and my embraces to a timeleſſe grave turne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here I'll ſtep in, for 'tis an act of merit.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I am too big to utter more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take time then.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This ſolitary life at home undoes thee,
obſcures thy beautie firſt, which ſhould prefer thee;
next fils thee full of ſad thoughts, which thy yeers
muſt not arrive at yet, they choak thy ſweetneſſe:
Follow the time, my girl, and it will bring thee
even to the fellowſhip of the nobleſt women,
Hellen her ſelf, to whom I would prefer thee,
and under whom this poor and private carriage
which I am onely able yet to reach at,
being caſt off, and all thy ſweets at luſtre,
will take thee as a fair friend, and preferre thee.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: Good Sir, be not ſo cruell as to ſeek
to kill that ſweet content y' have bred me to:
Have I not here enough to thank heaven for?
the free air uncorrupted with new flattery,
the water that I touch unbrib'd with odours
to make me ſweet to others: the pure fire
not ſmotherd up, and choak'd with luſtfull incenſe
to make my blood ſweat; but burning cleer and high,
tels me my minde muſt flame up ſo to heaven.
What ſhould I do at Court, wear rich apparell?
me thinks theſe are as warm: And for your ſtate, Sir,
wealthie enough; Is it you would have me proud,
and like a pageant, ſtuck up for amazements?
Teach not your child to tread that path, for fear (Sir)
your drie bones after death, groan in your grave
the miſeries that follow.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Excellent Caſta.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: When ſhall I pray again (a Courtier)?
or when I doe, to what God? what new body
and new face muſt I make me, with new manners?
for I muſt be no more my ſelf. Whoſe Miſtris
muſt I be firſt? with whoſe ſin-offring ſeaſon'd?
and when I am grown ſo great and glorious
with proſtitution of my burning beauties,
that great Lords kneel, and Princes beg for favours,
do you think I'll be your daughter, a poor Gentlemans,
or know you for my Father?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My beſt Caſta, Enter Lavall.
O my moſt vertuous childe, heaven reigns within thee;
take thine own choice, ſweet child, and live a ſaint ſtill.
The Lord Lavall; ſtand by, wench.

sp.speaker: Lav.

l.hi: Gabriella,

sp.l: ſhe cannot, nor ſhe dares not make it known,
my greatneſſe cruſhes her, when-ere ſhe offers:
why ſhould I fear her then?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, let's paſſe on wench.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Gentille, come hither: Who's that Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A child of mine, Sir, who obſerving cuſtome,
is going to the Monaſterie to her prayers.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: A fair one, a moſt ſweet one; fitter far
to beautifie a Court, then make a Votariſt.
Go on, fair Beautie, and in your Orizons
remember me: Will ye, fair ſweet?

sp.speaker: Casta.
sp.l: Moſt humbly. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: An admirable Beautie: how it fires me!
But ſhee's too full of grace, and I too wicked.
I feel my wonted fit: Defend mee, goodneſſe.
O, it growes colder ſtill, and ſtiffer on me,
my hair ſtands up, my ſinews ſhake and ſhrink:
Help me good heaven, and good thoughts dwel within me.
O get thee gone, thou evill evill ſpirit;
haunt me no more, I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Yes Lavall:
thou art my vaſſall, and the ſlave to miſchiefe,
I blaſt thee with new ſin: purſue thy pleaſure;
Caſta is rare and ſweet, a blowing Beautie;
ſet thy deſires afire, and never quench 'em
till thou enjoy'ſt her; make her all thy heaven,
and all thy joy, for ſhee is all true happineſſe:
Thou art powerfull, uſe command; if that prevail not,
force her; I'll be thy friend.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O help me, help me.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.p: Her vertue, like a ſpel, ſinke me to darkneſs. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: He's here ſtill. How is 't, noble Lord? me thinks, Sir,
you look a little wildly. Is it that way?
is't her you ſtare on ſo? I have ſpi'd your fire, Sir,
but dare not ſtay the flaming. Come.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sweet creature,
excellent Beautie, do me but the happineſſe
to be your humbleſt ſervant. O fair eyes,
O bleſſed, bleſſed ſweetneſſe, divine virgin.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: O good my Lord, retire into your honour:
you 're ſpoken good and vertuous, plac'd at helme
to govern others from miſchances: from example
of ſuch fair Chronicles as great ones are,
we do, or ſure we ſhould direct our lives.
I know y' are full of worth, a ſchool of vertue
daily inſtructing us that live below ye,
I make no doubt, dwels there.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I cannot anſwer,
ſhe has ſtruck me dumb with wonder.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: Goodneſſe guide ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: She's gone, and with her all light, and has left me
dark as my black deſires. O divell luſt,
how doſt thou hug my blood, and whiſper to me,
there is no day again, no time, no living,
without this luſtie Beautie break upon me?
Let me collect my ſelf, I ſtrive like billows,
beaten againſt a rock, and fall a fool ſtill.
I muſt enjoy her, and I will: from this hour
my thoughts and all my buſ'neſſe ſhall be nothing,
my eating, and my ſleeping, but her beautie,
and how to work it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Health to my Lord Lavall.
Nay good Sir, do not turn with ſuch diſpleaſure;
I come not to afflict your new born pleaſures;
my honour'd Miſtris, neither let that vex ye,
for nothing is intended but ſafe to you.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What of your Miſtris? I am full of buſ'neſſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will be ſhort, my Lord; ſhe, loving Lady,
conſidring the unequall tie between ye,
and how your ruine with the Duke lay on it,
as alſo the moſt noble match now made,
by me ſends back all links of marriage,
all holy vows, and rights of Ceremonie,
all promiſes, oathes, tears, and all ſuch pawnes
you left in hoſtage: onely her love ſhee cannot,
for that ſtill follows ye, but not to hurt ye;
and ſtill beholds ye Sir, but not to ſhame ye:
In recompence of which, this is her ſuit, Sir,
her poor and laſt petition, but to grant her,
when weary nights have cloy'd ye up with kiſſes,
(as ſuch muſt come) the honour of a Miſtris,
the honour but to let her ſee thoſe eyes,
(thoſe eyes ſhe doats on more then gods do goodneſſe)
and but to kiſſe ye onely: with this prayer,
(a prayer onely to awake your pitie)
and on her knees ſhe made it; that this night
you 'ld bleſſe her with your company at ſupper.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I like this well, and now I think on't better,
I'll make a preſent uſe from this occaſion:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, good my Lord, be not ſo cruell to her becauſe ſhe has been yours.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: and to mine own end
a rare way I will work.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can love for ever,
the love of her (my Lord) ſo periſh in ye?
as ye deſire in your deſires to proſper.
What gallant under heaven, but Anjou's heire then
can brag ſo fair a wife, and ſweet a Miſtris?
good noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Ye miſ-apply me, Mary,
nor do I want true pitie to your Ladie:
Pitie and love tell me, too much I have wrong'd her
to dare to ſee her more: yet ●f her ſweetneſſe
can entertain a mediation,
and it muſt be a great one that can cure me;
my love again, as far as honour bids me,
my ſervice and my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's nobly ſpoken.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Shall hourly ſee her; want ſhall never know her;
nor where ſhe has beſtow'd her love, repent her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now whither drives he?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I have heard, Maria,
that no two women in the world more lov'd,
then thy good Miſtris, and Gentilles fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What may this mean? You have heard a truth, my Lord:
but ſince the ſecret love betwixt you two,
my Miſtris durſt not entertain ſuch friendſhip;
Caſta is quick, and of a piercing judgement,
and quickly will finde out a flaw.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Hold Marie:
ſhrink not, 'tis good gold, wench: prepare a Banquet,
and get that Caſta thither; for ſhe's a creature
ſo full of forcible divine perſwaſion,
and ſo unwearied ever with good office,
and ſhe ſhall cure my ill cauſe to my Miſtris,
and make all errours up.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll doe my beſt Sir:
But ſhee's too fearfull, coy, and ſcrupulous,
to leave her fathers houſe ſo late; and baſhfull
at any mans appearance, that I fear Sir,
'twill prove impoſſi●le.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: There's more gold, Marie,
and fain thy Miſtris wondrous ſick to death, wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have ye in the wind now, and I'll pay ye.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Shee cannot chuſe but come; 'tis charitie,
the chief of her profeſſion: undertake this,
and I am there at night; if not, I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not looſe this offer, though it fall out
clean croſſe to that we caſt. I'll undertake it,
I will, my Lord; ſhe ſhall be there.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: By —?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By — ſhe ſhall.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Let it be ſomething late then,
for being ſeen. Now force or favour wins her.
My ſpirits are grown dull, ſtrong wine, and ſtore,
ſhall ſet 'em up again, and make mee fit
to draw home at the enterpriſe I aime at. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Go thy waies, falſe Lord, if thou hold'ſt, thou pai'ſt
the price of all thy luſts. Thou ſhalt be three,
thou modeſt maid, if I have any working,
and yet thy honour ſafe; for which this thief
I know has ſet this meeting: but I'll watch him.

l.hi: Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are mine eyes mine own? or bleſſe me,
am I deluded with a flying ſhadow?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Why do your ſtart ſo from me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It ſpeaks ſenſibly,
and ſhews a living body: yet I am fearfull.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Give me your hand, good Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He feels warm too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And next your lips.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He kiſſes perfectly.
Nay, and the divell be no worſe: you are Perolot.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I was, and ſure I ſhould be: Can a ſmall diſtance,
and ten ſhort months take from your memory
the figure of your friend, that you ſtand wondring?
Be not amaz'd, I am the ſelf-ſame Perolot,
living, and well; Son to Gentille, and Brother
to vertuous Caſta; to your beauteous Miſtris,
the long ſince poor betroth'd, and ſtill vow'd ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, ſure he lives. My Lord Lavall, your Maſter,
brought news long ſince to your much mourning Miſtris,
ye dy'd at Orleance; bound her with an oath too,
to keep it ſecret from your aged Father,
leſt it ſhould rack his heart.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: A pretty ſecret
to trie my Miſtris love, and make my welcome
from travel of more worth; from whence, heaven thanked,
my buſineſſe for the Duke diſpatch'd to th' purpoſe,
and all my money ſpent, I am come home, wench.
How does my Miſtris? for I have not yet ſeen
any, nor will I, till I doe her ſervice.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But did the Lord Lavall know of your love, Sir,
before ye went?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes: by much force he got it,
but none elſe knew; upon his promiſe too
and honour to conceal it faithfully
till my return; to further which, he told me,
my buſineſſe being ended, from the Duke
he would procure a penſion for my ſervice,
able to make my Miſtris a fit husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But are you ſure of this?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sure as my ſight, wench.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then is your Lord a baſe diſſembling villain,
a divell Lord, the damn'd Lord of all lewdneſſe,
and has betraid ye' and undone my Miſtris,
my poor ſweet Miſtris: Oh that leacher Lord,
who, poor ſoul, ſince was married.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: To whom, Maria?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: To that unluckie Lord, a —upon him;
whoſe hot horſe-appetite being allaid once
with her chaſte joyes, married again, ſcarce cool'd,
the torches yet not out the yellow Hymen
lighted about the bed, the ſongs yet ſounding,
Marine's young noble daughter Helena,
whoſe miſchief ſtands at door next. O that Recreant!

sp.speaker: Perolot.
sp.l: O villain! O moſt unmanly falſhood!
nay then I ſee, my letters were betraid too.
O, I am full of this, great with his miſchiefs,
loaden and burſt: Come lead me to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I cannot, Sir, Lavall keeps her conceal'd.
Beſides, her griefs are ſuch, ſhee will ſee no man.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I muſt and will goe to her: I will ſee her:
there be my friend, or this ſhall be thy furtheſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hold, and I'll help ye: But firſt ye ſhall ſwear to me,
as you are true and gentle, as ye hate
this beaſtly and baſe Lord, where I ſhall place ye,
(which ſhall be within ſight) till I diſcharge ye,
what-ere you ſee or hear, to make no motion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I doe by —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay here about the houſe then,
till it be later; yet the time's not perfect:
there at the back-door I'll attend you truly.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O monſtrous, monſtrous, beaſtly villain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How croſſe this falls, and from all expectation?
and what the end ſhall be, heaven onely yet knows:
onely I wiſh, and hope. But I forget ſtill,
Casta muſt be the bait, or all miſcarries.

div.stage: Enter Gentille with a torch: Shaloon above.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Holla, Shaloon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: A word from the Duke, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Tell your Lord he muſt to Court ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: He is ill at eaſe, and prayes he may be pardon'd
the occaſions of this night.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Belike, he is drunk then:
he muſt away; the Duke, and his fair Ladie,
the beauteous Helena, are now at Cent;
of whom ſhe has ſuch fortune in her carding,
the Duke has loſt a thouſand Crowns, and ſwears,
hee will not goe to bed, till by Lavall
the tide of loſſe be turn'd again. Awake him,
for 'tis the pleaſure of the Duke he muſt riſe.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Having ſo ſtrict command (Sir) to the contrary,
I dare not do it: I beſeech your pardon.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Are you ſure he is there?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: And aſleep?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: And are you ſure you wil not tell him, Shalon?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yes, very ſure.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Then I am ſure, I will.
Open, or I muſt force.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Pray ye ſtay: he is not,
nor will not be this night. You may excuſe it.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I knew he was gone about ſome womans labour.
As good a neighbour, though I ſay it, and as comfortable:
many ſuch more we need Shaloon. Alas, poor Ladie,
thou art like to lie croſſe-legg'd to night. Good Monſieur,
I will excuſe your Maſter for this once, Sir,
becauſe ſometimes I have lov'd a wench my ſelf too.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Tis a good hearing Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: But for your lye, Shaloon,
if I had you here, it ſhould be no good hearing,
for your pate I would pummell.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A fair good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Good night, thou noble Knight, Sir Pandarus.
My heart is cold o'th ſudden, and a ſtrange dulneſſe
poſſeſſes all my bodie: thy will be done heaven.

div.stage: Enter Gabriella and Casta: and Maria with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: 'Faith friend, I was even going to my bed,
when your maid told me of your ſudden ſickneſſe:
but from my grave (ſo truly I loue you)
I think your name would raiſe me: ye looke ill
ſince laſt I ſaw ye, much decai'd in colour:
yet I thanck heaven, I finde no ſuch great danger
as your maid frighted me withall: take courage
and give your ſickneſſe courſe: ſome griefe you have got
that feeds within upon your tender ſpirits,
and wanting open way to vent it ſelfe
murders your mind, and choakes up all your ſweetneſſe,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: It was my maids fault; worthy friend to trouble ye,
ſo late, upon ſo light a cauſe: yet ſure I have ye
O my deare Caſta.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: Out with it Gods name.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: The cloſſet of my heart, I will lock here, wench,
and things ſhal make ye tremble. Who's that knocks there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis Lavall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Sit you ſtill. Let him in.
In am reſolv'd, and all you wronged women,
you noble ſpirits, that as I have ſufferd
under this glorious beaſt-inſulting man,
lend me your cauſes, then your cruelties,
for I muſt put on madneſſe above women.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: Why do you look ſo ghaſtly?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Peace; no harm, Deer. Enter Lavall.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: There, take my cloak and ſword: Where is this Banquet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In the next room,

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: How came he here? Heaven bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Give me ſome wine wench; fill it ful, and ſprightly.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Sit ſtill, and be not fearfull.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Till my veins ſwell,
and my ſtrong ſinews ſtretch like that brave Centaur
that at the table ſnatch'd the Bride away
in ſpight of Hercules.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: I am betraid.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Nay ſtart not Ladie; 'tis for you that I come,
and for your beautie: 'tis for you, Lavall
honours this night; to you, the ſacred ſhrine
I humbly bow, offring my vows and prayers;
to you I live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: In with the powder quickly:
ſo, that and the wine will rock ye.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Here, to the health
of the moſt beauteous and divine, fair Caſta,
the ſtar of ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Fear him not, I'll die firſt.
And who ſhall pledge ye?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt, thou tann'd Gipſey:
and worſhip to that brightneſſe give, cold Tartar.
By — ye ſhall not ſtir; ye are my Miſtris,
the glory of my love, the great adventure,
the Miſtris of my heart, and ſhee my whore.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thou ly'ſt, baſe, beaſtly Lord; drunker then anger,
thou ſowſed Lord, got by a ſurfeit, thou lyeſt baſely.
Nay, ſtir not; I dare tell thee ſo. Sit you ſtill.
If I be whore, it is in marrying thee,
that art ſo abſolute and full a villain,
no Sacrament can ſave that piece tied to thee.
How often haſt thou woo'd in thoſe flatteries,
almoſt thoſe very words, my conſtancie?
what goddeſſe have I not been, or what goodneſſe?
what ſtar that is of any name in heaven,
or brightneſſe? which of all the vertues
(but drunkenneſſe, and drabbing, thy two morals)
have not I reach'd to? what Spring was ever ſweeter?
what Scythian ſnow ſo white? what cryſtal chaſter?
Is not thy new wife now the ſame too? Hang thee,
baſe Bigamiſt, thou honour of ill women.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: How's this? O heaven defend me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thou ſalt-itch;
for whom no cure but ever burning brimſtone
can be imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Doſt thou laugh, thou breaker
of all law, all religion, of all faith
thou foul contemner?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Peace, thou paltry woman:
and ſit by me, Sweet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: By the Divell?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Come,
and lull me with delights.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: It works amain now.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Give me ſuch kiſſes as the Queen of ſhadows
gave to the ſleeping boy ſhe ſtole on ●atmus;
lock round about in ſnakie wreathes cloſe folded,
thoſe roſie arms about my neck, O Venus.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Fear not, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thou admirable ſweetneſſe,
diſtill thy bleſſings like thoſe ſilver drops,
that falling on fair grounds, riſe all in roſes:
Shoot me a thouſand darts from thoſe fair eyes,
and through my heart transfix 'em all, I'll ſtand 'em.
Send me a thouſand ſmiles, and preſently
I'll catch 'em in mine eyes, and by Love's power
turn 'em to Cupids all, and fling 'em on thee.
How high ſhe looks, and heavenly! More wine for me.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.l: Give him more wine, and good friend be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Here on my knee, thou goddeſſe of delights,
this luſtie grape I offer to thy Beauties;
ſee how it leaps to view that perfect redneſſe
that dwels upon thy lips: now, how it bluſhes
to be outbluſh'd. Oh let me feed my fancie,
and as I hold the purple god in one hand
dancing about the brim' and proudly ſwelling,
deck'd in the pride of nature young, and blowing;
ſo let me take fair Semele in the other,
and ſing the loves of gods, then drink, their Nectar's
not yet deſir'd.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Then like luſtie Tarquin
turn'd into flames with Lucrece coy denyals,
his blood and ſpirit equally ambitious,
I force thee for mine own.

sp.speaker: Caſta.
sp.l: O help me, Juſtice:
help me, my Chaſtitie.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Now I am bravely quarried. Perolot above.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, bawdy ſlave, no Treacher, ſhe is not carried.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: She's looſe again, and gone. I'll keep my place ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now it works bravely: ſtand, he cannot hurt ye.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: O my ſweet Love, my life. Hee falls downe, and ſleeps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He ſinks.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, now he is ſafe a while.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Lock all the doors, wench,
then for my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Now I'll appear to know all.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Be quick, quick, good Marie, ſure and ſudden.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Stay, I muſt in firſt.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O' my conſcience
it is young Perolet: O my ſtung conſcience!
it is my firſt and nobleſt Love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Leave wondring,
and recollect your ſelf: the man is living,
equally wrong'd as you, and by that divell.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt true, Ladie: your unhappie fortune
I grieve for as mine own, your fault forgive too,
if it be one. This is no time for kiſſes:
I have heard all, and known all, which mine eares
are crack'd apieces with, and my heart periſh'd.
I ſaw him in your chamber, ſaw his fury,
and am afire till I have found his heart out.
What do you mean to doe? for I'll make one.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: To make his death more horrid (for he ſhall die)

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He muſt, he muſt.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: wee'll watch him till he wakes,
then bind him, and then torture him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing.
No, take him dead drunk now without repentance,
his leacherie inſeam'd upon him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I'll do it my ſelf; and when 'tis done, provide ye,
for wee'll away for Italie this night.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Wee'll follow thorow all hazzards.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O falſe Lord,
unmanly, miſchievous; how I could curſe thee.
But that but blaſts thy fame; have at thy heart, fool:
loop-holes I'll make enough to let thy life out.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Oh, does the divell ride me?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Murder.
Nay, then take my ſhare too.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Help; Oh, he has ſlain me.
Bloody intentions muſt have blood.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Heaven.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: He ſinks, he ſinks, for ever ſinks: O fortune!
O ſorrow, how like ſeas thou floweſt upon me!
Here will I dwell for ever. Weep, Maria,
weep this young mans misfortune: O thou trueſt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What have I done?

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: That that has mark'd thy ſoul man.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: And art thou come again, thou diſmall ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Yes, to devour thy laſt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Mercie upon me.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Thy hour is come: Succeſſion, honour, pleaſure,
and all the luſtre thou ſo long haſt look'd for
muſt here have end: Summon thy ſins before thee.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O my affrighted ſoul!

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: There lies a black one;
thy owne beſt ſervant by thy own hand ſlain,
thy drunkenneſſe procur'd it: There's another,
think of fair Gabriella, there ſhe weeps;
and ſuch tears are not loſt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O miſerable!

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Thy foul intention to the vertuous Caſta.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: No more, no more, thou wild-fire.

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Laſt, thy laſt wife,
think on the wrong ſhe ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O my miſerie,
oh, whither ſhall I flie?

sp.speaker: Spir.
sp.l: Thou haſt no faith, fool.
Heark to thy knell. Sings, and vaniſhes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Millions of ſins muſter about mine eyes now:
murders, ambitions, luſt, falſe faiths; O horror,
in what a ſtormie form of death thou rid'ſt now!
Me thinks I ſee all tortures, fires, and froſts,
deep ſinking caves, where nothing but deſpair dwels,
the balefull birds of night hovering about 'em;
a grave, me thinks, now opens, and a herſe
hung with my Arms tumbles into it: oh,
oh, my afflicted ſoule: I cannot pray;
and the leaſt childe that has but gooddeſſe in him
may ſtrike my head off; ſo ſtupid are my powers:
I'll lift mine eyes up though.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ceaſe theſe laments,
they are too poor for vengeance: Lavall lives yet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Then thus I drie all ſorrows from theſe eyes,
fury and rage poſſeſſe 'em now: damn'd divell.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This for young Perolot.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O mercy, mercy.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This for my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: But one ſhort hour to cure mee.
oh be not cruell: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heark, they knock.
make haſte for heavens ſake, Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: This for Casta.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Oh, O, O, O. He dies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's dead: come quickly, let 's away with him,
't will be too late elſe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Help, help up to th' chamber.

div.stage: Enter Duke, Hellena, Gentile, Caſta, and attendants, with lights.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What frights are theſe?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I am ſure here's one paſt frighting.
Bring the lights neerer: I have enough alreadie.
Out, out, mine eyes. Look, Casta.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'T is young Perolot.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When came he over? Hold the Gentlewoman,
ſhe ſinks; and bear her off.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: O my dear brother! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There is a time for all; for me, I hope, too,
and very ſhortly. Murdred?

div.stage: Gabriella, Maria, with Lavalls body, above.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who 's above there?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Look up, and ſee.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What may this mean?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Behold it;
behold the drunken murderer
of that young Gentleman; behold the rankeſt,
the vileſt, baſeſt ſlave that ever flouriſh'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who kill'd him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I; and there 's the cauſe I did it:
read, if your eyes will give you leave.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Oh monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Nay, out it ſhall: there, take this falſe heart to ye,
the baſe diſhonour of a thouſand women:
keep it in gold, Duke, 't is a precious jewel.
Now to my ſelf; for I have liv'd a fair age,
longer by ſome moneths then I had a minde to.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hold.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Here, young Perolot; my firſt contracted
true love ſhall never go alone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Hold, Gabriella,
I do forgive all.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I ſhall die the better.
Thus let me ſeek my grave, and my ſhames with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor ſhalt thou go alone my noble Miſtris:
why ſhould I live, and thou dead?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Save the wench there.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She is; I hope; and all my ſins here written.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This was a fatal night.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Heaven has his working,
which we cannot contend againſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Alas.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your Grace has your alas too.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Would 't were equal;
for thou haſt loſt an honeſt noble childe.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: 'T is heir enough has loſt a good remembrance.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: See all their bodies buried decently,
though ſome deſerv'd it not. How do you, Ladie?

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Even with your Graces leave, ripe for a Monaſterie;
there will I wed my life to tears and prayers,
and never know what man is more.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your pleaſure;
how does the maid within?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: She is gone before, Sir,
the ſame courſe that my Ladie takes.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And my courſe ſhall be my Beads at home; ſo
pleaſe your Grace to give me leave to leave the Court.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: In peace, Sir,
and take my love along.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I ſhall pray for ye.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now to our ſelves retire we, and begin
by this example to correct each ſin. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King. Em.
sp.l: By this we plainly view the two impoſthumes
that choke a kingdoms welfare; Eaſe, and Wantonneſſe;
in both of which Lavall was capital:
for firſt, Eaſe ſtole away his minde from honour,
that active noble thoughts had kept ſtill working,
and then deliver'd him to drink and women,
luſt and outragious riot; and what their ends are,
how infamous and foul, we ſee example.
Therefore, that great man that will keep his name,
and gain his merit out of Vertues ſchools,
muſt make the pleaſures of the world his fools.

div.stage: Enter Muſicians: next them, Perolot with the wound he died with. Then Gabriella and Maria, with their wounds: after them, four Furies with Bannerets inſcrib'd Revenge, Murder, Luſt and Drunkenneſſe, ſinging. Next them, La|vall wounded. Then a Chariot with Death, drawn by the Deſtinies. Flouriſh.

l.hi: From this ſad ſight aſcend your noble eye,

sp.l: And ſee old Time helping triumphantly
helping his Master Man: view here his vanities,

l.hi: and ſee his falſe friends like thoſe glutted flyes,
that when they 've ſuckt their fill, fall off, and fade
from all remembrance of him, like a ſhade.
And laſt, view who relieves him; and that gone,
We hope your favour, and our Play is done.

div.stage: Enter Anthropos, Deſire, and Vain Delight; Bounty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What haſt thou done, Deſire, and how imploy'd
the charge I gave thee, about levying wealth
for our ſupplies?

sp.speaker: Deſire.
sp.l: I have done all, yet nothing:
tri'd all, and all my ways, yet all miſcarried;
there dwells a ſordid dulneſſe in their mindes.
Thou ſon of earth, colder then that thou art made of,
I came to Craft, found all his hooks about him,
and all his nets baited and ſet; his ſlie ſelf
and greedie Lucre at a ſe●ious conference
which way to tie the world within their ſtatutes a
buſineſſe of all ſides and of all ſorts ſwarming
like Bees broke looſe in ſummer: I declared
your will and want together, both inforcing
with all the power and pains I had, to reach him;
yet all fell ſhort.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: His anſwer.

sp.speaker: Deſire.
sp.l: This he gave me.
Your wants are never ending; and thoſe ſupplies
that came to ſtop thoſe breaches, are ever laviſht
before they reach the main, in toys and trifles,
gew-gaws, and gilded puppets: Vain delight
he ſays has ruin'd ye, with clapping all
that comes in for ſupport, on clothes, and Coaches,
perfumes, and powder'd pates; and that your Miſtris,
the Ladie Pleaſure, like a ſea devours
at length both you and him too. If you have houſes,
or land, or jewels, for good pawn, he'll hear you,
and will be readie to ſupplie occaſions;
if not, he locks his ears up, and grows ſtupid.
From him, I went to Vanity▪ whom I found
attended by an endleſſe troop of Tailors,
Mercers, Embroiderers, Feather-makers, Fumers,
all Occupations opening like a Mart,
that ſerve to rig the bodie out with braverie;
and th'row the room new faſhions flew like flyes,
in thouſand gaudie ſhapes; Pride waiting on her,
and buſily ſurveying all the breaches
Time and delaying Nature had wrought in her,
which ſtill with art ſhe piec'd again, and ſtrengthened:
I told your wants; ſhe ſhew'd me gowns and head-tires,
imbroider'd waſtcoats, ſmocks ſeam'd thorow with cut-works,
ſcarfs, mantles, petticoats, muffs, powders, paintings,
dogs, monkeys, parrots, which all ſeemed to ſhew me
the way her money went. From her to Pleaſure
I took my journey.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And what ſays our beſt Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Deſire.
sp.l: She danc'd me out this anſwer preſently:
Revels and Maſques had drawn her drie alreadie.
I met old Time too, mowing mankinde down,
who ſays you are too hot, and he muſt purge ye.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A cold quietus. Miſerable creatures,
born to ſupport and beautifie your maſter,
the godlike man, ſet here to do me ſervice,
the children of my will; why, or how dare ye,
created to my uſe alone, diſgrace me?
Beaſts have more courteſie; they live about me,
offering their warm wooll to the ſhearers hand,
to clothe me with their bodies to my labours;
nay, even their lives they daily ſacrifice,
and proudly preſſe with garlands to the altars,
to fill the gods oblations. Birds bow to me,
ſtriking their downie ſails to do me ſervice,
their ſweet airs ever ecchoing to mine honour,
and to my reſt their plumie ſofts they ſend me.
Fiſhes, and plants, and all where life inhabits,
but mine own curſed kinde, obey their ruler;
mine have forgot me, miſerable mine,
into whoſe ſtonie hearts, neglect of dutie,
ſquint-ey'd deceit, and ſelf-love, are crept cloſely:
none feel my wants, not one mend with me.

sp.speaker: Deſire.
sp.l: None, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou haſt forgot (Deſire) thy beſt friend, Flatterie;
he cannot fail me.

sp.speaker: Delight.
sp.l: Fail? he will ſell himſelf,
and all within his power, cloſe to his skin firſt.

sp.speaker: Deſire.
sp.l: I thought ſo too, and made him my firſt venture,
but found him in a young Lords ear ſo buſie,
ſo like a ſmiling ſhowr pouring his ſoul
in at his portals, his face in thouſand figures
catching the vain minde of the man: I pull'd him,
but ſtill he hung like birdlime; ſpoke unto him,
his anſwer ſtill was, By the Lord, ſweet Lord,
and By my ſoul, thou maſter-piece of honour;
nothing could ſtave him off: he has heard your flood's gone;
and on decaying things he ſeldom ſmiles, Sir.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Then here I break up ſtate, and free my followers,
putting my fortune now to Time, and Juſtice:
go ſeek new maſters now; for Anthropos
neglected by his friends, muſt ſeek new fortunes.
Deſire, to Avarice I here commend thee,
where thou may'ſt live at full bent of thy wiſhes:
and Vain Delight, thou feeder of my follies
with light fantaſtickneſſe, be thou in favour.
To leave thee, Bountie, my moſt worthie ſervant,
troubles me more then mine own miſery;
but we muſt part: go plant thy ſelf, my beſt friend,
in honourable hearts that truely know thee,
and there live ever like thy ſelf, a vertue:
but leave this place, and ſeek the Countrey
for Law; and luſt like fire lick all up here.
Now none but Poverty, muſt follow me,
deſpis'd patch'd Poverty; and we two married,
will ſeek Simplicity, Content and Peace out,
and live with them in exile. How uncall'd on
my true friend comes!

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.l: Here, hold thee, Anthropos,
thou art almoſt arm'd at reſt; put this on,
a penitential robe, to purge thy pleaſures:
off with that vanitie.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Here, Vain Delight,
and with this all my part, to thee again
of thee I freely render.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.l: Take this ſtaff now,
and be more conſtant to your ſteps hereafter:
the ſtaff is Staidneſſe of affections.
Away, you painted flyes, that with mans ſummer
take life and heat buzzing about his bloſſoms;
when growing full, ye turn to Caterpillers,
gnawing the root that gave you life. Fly ſhadows.
Now to Content I'll give thee, Anthropos,
to Rest and Peace: no vanitie dwells there;
Deſire nor Pleaſure, to delude thy minde more;
no Flatteries ſmooth-fil'd tongue ſhall poiſon thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O Jupiter, if I have ever offer'd
upon thy burning Altars but one Sacrifice
thou and thy fair-ey'd Juno ſmil'd upon;
if ever, to thine honour, bounteous feaſts,
where all thy ſtatues ſweat with wine and incenſe,
have by the ſon of earth been celebrated:
hear me (the childe of ſhame now) hear, thou helper,
and take my wrongs into thy hands, thou juſtice,
done by unmindful man, unmerciful,
againſt his maſter done, againſt thy order;
and raiſe again, thou father of all honour,
the poor deſpis'd, but yet thy nobleſt creature.
Raiſe from his ruines once more this ſunk Cedar,
that all may fear thy power, and I proclaim it.

div.stage: Jupiter and Mercury deſcend ſeverally. Trumpets ſmall above.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Hoa; Mercury, my winged ſon.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Whoſe powerful prayers were thoſe that reach'd our ears,
arm'd in ſuch ſpells of pitie now?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The ſad petitions
of the ſcorn'd ſon of earth, the godlike Anthropos,
he that has ſwell'd your ſacred fires with incenſe,
and pil'd upon your altars thouſand heifers;
he that (beguil'd by Vanity and Pleaſure,
Deſire, Craft, Flattery, and ſmooth Hypocriſie)
ſtands now deſpis'd and ruin'd, left to Poverty.

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: It muſt not be; he was not rais'd for ruine;
nor ſhall thoſe hands heav'd at mine altars periſh:
he is our nobleſt creature. Flee to Time,
and charge him preſently releaſe the bands
of Poverty and Want this ſuiter ſinks in:
tell him, among the ſun-burnt Indians,
that know no other wealth but peace and pleaſure,
ſhe ſhall finde golden Plutus, god of riches,
who idly is ador'd, the innocent people
not knowing yet what power and weight he carries:
bid him compel him to his right uſe, honour,
and preſently to live with Anthropos.
It is our will. Away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I do obey it.

div.stage: Muſick. Enter Plutus, with a troop of Indians ſinging and dancing wildly about him, and bowing to him: which ended, enter Time.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Riſe, and away; 't is Joves command.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: I will not:
ye have ſome fool to furniſh now; ſome Midas
that to no purpoſe I muſt choke with riches.
Who muſt I go to?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: To the ſon of earth;
he wants the god of wealth.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Let him want ſtill:
I was too lately with him, almoſt torn
into ten thouſand pieces by his followers:
I could not ſleep, but Craft or Vanity
were filing off my fingers; not eat, for fear
Pleaſure would caſt her ſelf into my bellie,
and there ſurpriſe my heart.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Theſe have forſaken him:
make haſte then; thou muſt with me: be not angrie,
for fear a greater anger light upon thee.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: I do obey then: but change my figure;
for when I willingly befriend a creature,
goodly and full of glory I ſhew to him;
but when I am compell'd, old, and decrepit,
I halt, and hang upon my ſtaff. Fare well, friends,
I will not be long from ye; all my ſervants
I leave among ye ſtill, and my chief riches.
O Time, what innocence dwells here, what goodneſſe!
they know me not, nor hurt me not, yet hug me.
Away, I'll follow thee: but not too faſt, Time.

div.stage: Enter Anthropos, Honeſtie, Simplicitie, Humilitie, Povertie.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Man, be not ſad, nor let this divorce
from Mundus, and his many ways of pleaſure,
afflict thy ſpirits; which conſider'd rightly
with inward eyes, makes thee arrive at happie.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.l: For now what danger or deceit can reach thee?
what matter left for Craft or Covetize
to plot againſt thee? what Deſire to burn thee?

sp.speaker: Honeſt.
sp.l: O ſon of earth, let Honeſtie poſſeſſe thee;
be as thou waſt intended, like thy Maker;
ſee thorow thoſe gawdie ſhadows, that like dreams
have dwelt upon thee long: call up thy goodneſſe,
thy minde and man within thee, that lie ſhipwrack'd,
and then how thin and vain theſe fond affections,
how lame this worldly love, how lumplike raw
and ill-digeſted all theſe vanities
will ſhew, let Reaſon tell thee,

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.l: Crown thy minde
with that above the worlds wealth, joyful ſuffring,
and truely be the maſter of thy ſelf,
which is the nobleſt Empire; and there ſtand
the thing thou wert ordain'd, and ſet to govern.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Come, let us ſing the worlds ſhame: hear us, Anthropos.

div.stage: Song: and then enter Time and Plutus.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Away; we are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Get thou too after,
thou needie bare companion; go for ever,
for ever, I conjure thee: make no anſwer.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What mak'ſt thou here, Time? thou that to this
minute never ſtood'ſt ſtill by me?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: I have brought thee ſuccour;
and now catch hold, I am thine: The god of riches
(compell'd by him that ſaw thy miſeries,
the ever juſt and wakeful Jove, at length)
is come unto thee: uſe him as thine own;
for 't is the doom of heaven: he muſt obey thee.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Have I found pitie then?

sp.speaker: Time.
sp.l: Thou haſt; and Justice
againſt thoſe falſe ſeducers of thine honour:
Come, give him preſent helps.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Come, Induſtrie,
thou friend of life: and next to thee, riſe Labour;
riſe preſently: and now to your employments;
but firſt conduct this mortal to the rock.
sp.stage: They carry Anthropos to a rock, and fall a digging.
sp.l: What ſeeſt thou now?

div.stage: Plutus ſtrikes the rock, and flames flie out.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A glorious mine of metal.
O Jupiter, my thanks.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: To me a little.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And to the god of wealth my Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: Nay, then I am rewarded. Take heed now, ſon,
you are afloat again, leſt Mundus catch ye.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Never betray me more.

sp.speaker: Plut.
sp.l: I muſt to India,
from whence I came, where my main wealth lies buried,
and theſe muſt with me. Take that book and mattock,
and by thoſe know to live again.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I ſhall do.

sp.speaker: Fame.
sp.l: Thorow all the world the fortune of great Anthr.
be known and wonder'd at; his riches envi'd
as far as Sun or Time is; his power fear'd too.

div.stage: Muſick. Enter Delight, Pleaſure, Craft, Lucre, Vanitie, &c. dancing (and mask'd) towards the Rock, offering ſervice to Anthropos. Mercury from above. Muſick heard. One half of a cloud drawn. Singers are diſcovered: then the other half drawn. Jupi|ter ſeen in glory.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Take heed, weak man, thoſe are the ſins that ſunk thee:
truſt 'em no more: kneel, and give thanks to Jupiter.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O mighty power!

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Unmask, ye gilded poiſons:
now look upon 'em, ſon of earth, and ſhame 'em;
now ſee the faces of thy evil angels,
lead 'em to Time, and let 'em fill his Triumph:
their memories be here forgot for ever.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: O juſt great god! how many lives of ſervice,
what ages onely given to thine honour,
what infinites of vows and holy prayers,
can pay my thanks?

sp.speaker: Jup.
sp.l: Riſe up: and to aſſure thee
that never more thou ſhalt feel want, ſtrike, Mercury,
ſtrike him; and by that ſtroke he ſhall for ever
live in that rock of gold, and ſtill enjoy it.
Be done, I ſay. Now ſing in honour of him.

div.stage: Firſt the Muſicians: Then Vain Delight, Plea|ſure, Craft, Lucre, Vanitie, and other of the Vi|ces: Then a Chariot with the perſon of Time ſitting in it; drawn by four perſons repreſent|ing Hours, ſinging.

sp.speaker: King. Em.
sp.l: By this we note (ſweet heart) in Kings and Princes
a weakneſſe, even in ſpite of all their wiſedoms,
and often to be maſter'd by abuſes:
Our natures here deſcrib'd too, and what humours
prevail above our Reaſons to undo us.
But this the laſt and beſt, When no friend ſtands,
The gods are merciful, and lend their hands.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: Now as the Husbandman, whoſe Coſts and Pain,
Whoſe Hopes and Helps lie buried in his Grain,
Waiting a happie Spring, to ripen full
His long'd-for Harveſt to the Reapers pull;
Stand we expecting, having ſown our Ground
with ſo much charge (the fruitfulneſſe not found)
the Harvest of our Labours: For we know
You are our Spring; and when you ſmile, we grow.
Nor Charge nor Pain ſhall binde us from your Pleaſures,
So you but lend your hands to fill our Meaſures.
